Problem:
Consider a linear system defined by the partial differential equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\), where L is a linear differential operator. We explore the implications of applying a Fourier transform \\( F(u) = \\hat{u} \\) to the system, affecting the solution characteristics over time t.

If the Fourier transform \\( F(u) \\) is applied to an initial function \\( u_0 \\) at t = 0, and then the system is allowed to evolve under \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\) without further intervention, will \\( u(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( u_0 \\) was evolved directly under \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = Lu\\) to t = T?
Explanation: The Fourier transform modifies the initial function into its frequency components, changing how the operator L acts on \\( u(t) \\). Since L may affect different frequency components variously, \\( u(t) \\) at time T will not generally match the untransformed evolution.
